titleStmt.title: Approaches to multiple attribute group decision making based on intuitionistic fuzzy power aggregation operators

affiliation.orgName: PLA University of Science and Technology

analytic.title: Approaches to multiple attribute group decision making based on intuitionistic fuzzy power aggregation operators

biblStruct.note: Received 6 August 2010 Received in revised form 9 December 2010 Accepted 27 January 2011

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Multiple attribute group decision making Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy set Power average operator Power geometric operator Intuitionistic fuzzy number

div.p: Intuitionistic fuzzy numbers (IFNs) are very suitable to be used for depicting uncertain or fuzzy information. Motivated by the idea of power aggregation [R.R. Yager, The power average operator, IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics-Part A 31 (2001) 724-731], in this paper, we develop a series of operators for aggregating IFNs, establish various properties of these power aggregation operators, and then apply them to develop some approaches to multiple attribute group decision making with Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy information. Moreover, we extend these aggregation operators and decision making approaches to interval-valued Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy environments.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Intuitionistic fuzzy set (A-IFS), introduced by Atanassov [1], is the generalization of Zadeh's fuzzy set [29]. A-IFS is characterized by a membership function and a nonmembership function, and thus can depict the fuzzy character of data more detailedly and comprehensively than Zadeh's fuzzy set which is only characterized by a membership function. For example, if a girl wants to find a boy friend, and evaluates the boy from five aspects, she may feel satisfied with three aspects, unsatisfied with one aspect and uncertain with one aspect of the boy. In such a case, fuzzy sets can only reflect the satisfied aspects, which loses some uncertain information, while A-IFSs can describe all the satisfied, unsatisfied and uncertain information. In a variety of voting events, in addition to the support and objection, there is usually the abstention which indicates the hesitation and indeterminacy of the voter to the object. A-IFSs are more suitable to deal with these cases than fuzzy sets. The core of an A-IFS is intuitionistic fuzzy number (IFN) [21,14], which is composed of the membership degree and nonmembership degree. IFNs are a very useful tool to express a decision maker's preference information over objects in the process of decision making under uncertain or vague environments. In order to get a decision result, an important step is the aggregation of IFNs. Recently, some operators have been given to aggregate IFNs [21][22][23][14][15][16]12,13,3,27,30,20,5,17,18], such as intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted averaging operator, intuitionistic fuzzy ordered weighted geometric operator, and intuitionistic fuzzy hybrid aggregation operators. However, all these aggregation operators do not take into account the information about the relationship between the values being fused. To overcome this drawback, motivated by the idea of power aggregation [26], in this paper, we develop a series of intuitionistic fuzzy aggregation operators, whose weighting vectors depend upon the input arguments and allow values being aggregated to support and reinforce each other, and study their desirable properties. Then based on these aggregation operators, we develop some approaches to multiple attribute group decision making with Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy information. We also extend the developed operators and decision making approaches to interval-valued Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy environments [2] in which the input data take the form of interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy numbers [11,28,30].

div.head: Power aggregation operators
div.p: Information aggregation is a process that fuses data from various resources by using a proper aggregation technique. In order to provide a tool to aid and provide more versatility in the data aggregation process, Yager [26] introduced a power average (PA) operator to aggregate a collection of data a i (i = 1,2,. . . , n), defined as follows:
PAða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼
div.formula: P n i¼1 ð1 þ Tða i ÞÞa i P n i¼1 ð1 þ Tða i ÞÞð1Þ
div.p: where Tða i Þ ¼ P n j¼1 j-i Supða i ; a j Þ, and Sup(a i ,a j ) is the support for a i from a j , which satisfies the properties: (1) Sup(a i , a j ) 2 [0,1]; (2) Sup(a i , a j ) = Sup(a j , a i ); (3) Sup(a i , a j ) P Sup(a s , a t ), if ja i À a j j < ja s À a t j.
Based on the PA operator and the geometric mean, Xu and Yager [24] further defined a power geometric (PG) operator:
div.formula: a n Þ ¼ Y n i¼1 a 1þTða i Þ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ ið2Þ
div.p: Obviously, the PA and PG operators are a nonlinear weighted aggregation tool, whose weighting vectors depend upon the input data and allow values being aggregated to support and reinforce each other, that is, the closer two values a i and a j , the more similar they are, and the more they support each other.

div.head: Intuitionistic fuzzy numbers
div.p: Atanassov [1] introduced the concept of intuitionistic fuzzy set (A-IFS):
Definition 1 [1]. Let E be a fixed set, then
div.formula: A ¼ fhx; l A ðxÞ; v A ðxÞijx 2 Eg ð 3Þ
div.p: is called an Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy set (A-IFS), which assigns to each element x a membership degree l A (x) and a nonmembership degree v A (x), with the condition l A (x), v A (x) P 0 and 0 6 l A (x) + v A (x) 6 1, "x 2 E. Furthermore, p A (x) = 1 À l A (x) À v A (x) ("x 2 E) is called a hesitancy degree or intuitionistic index of x in A.
In the special case p A (x) = 0, i.e., l A (x) + v A (x) = 1, the A-IFS A reduces to a fuzzy set [29].

Xu and Yager [21] called each triple (l A (x), v A (x), p A (x)) an intuitionistic fuzzy number (IFN), and for convenience, denoted an IFN by a = (l a , v a , p a ), where l a ; v a P 0; l a þ v a 6 1; p a ¼ 1 À l a À v a ð4Þ Each IFN has a physical interpretation, for example, if a = (0.6, 0.3), then l a = 0.6, v a = 0.3 and p a = 0.1, which can be interpreted as ''the vote for resolution is 6 in favor, 3 against, and 1 abstentions''.
For an IFNs a, Chen and Tan [4] introduced the score function s a to get the score of a. Later, Hong and Choi [7] defined the accuracy function h a to evaluate the accuracy degree of a:
div.formula: s a ¼ l a À v að5Þ
h a ¼ l a þ v að6Þ
div.p: Based on the score function and the accuracy function, Xu and Yager [21], Xu [14] gave an order relation between any two IFNs: Definition 2 ( [14,21]). Let a i ¼ ðl a i ; v a i ; p a Þ ði ¼ 1; 2Þ be any two IFNs, s a i and h a i ði ¼ 1; 2Þ be the scores and accuracy degrees of a i
div.formula: (i = 1, 2), respectively, then If s a 1 > s a 2 , then a 1 > a 2 ; If s a 1 ¼ s a 2 , then (1) If h a 1 ¼ h a 2 , then a 1 = a 2 ; (2) If h a 1 > h a 2 , then a 1 > a 2 .
div.p: Xu and Yager [21], Xu [14] also introduced some operational laws of IFNs as follows: Definition 3. Let a i ¼ ðl a i ; v a i ; p a i Þ ði ¼ 1; 2Þ be any two IFNs, then (1)
div.formula: a 1 È a 2 ¼ ðl a 1 þ l a 2 À l a 1 l a 2 ; v a 1 v a 2 ; ð1 À l a 1 Þð1 À l a 2 Þ Àv a 1 v a 2 Þ; (2) a 1 a 2 ¼ ðl a 1 l a 2 ; v a 1 þ v a 2 À v a 1 v a 2 ; ð1 À v a 1 Þð1 À v a 2 Þ Àl a 1 l a 2 Þ; (3) ka 1 ¼ ð1 À ð1 À l a 1 Þ k ; v k a 1 ; ð1 À l a 1 Þ k À v k a 1 Þ, k > 0; (4) a k 1 ¼ ðl k a 1 ; 1 À ð1 À v a 1 Þ k ; ð1 À v a 1 Þ k À l k a 1 Þ, k > 0.
div.p: All the results of the above operations are also IFNs and the followings are all right:
div.formula: (1) If k 1 > k 2 , then k 1 a P k 2 a, a 1Àk 1 P a 1Àk 2 , 0 < k 1 , k 2 6 1;
div.p: (2) If l a 1 P l a 2 , v a 1 6 v a 2 , then ka 1 P ka 2 ; a k
div.formula: 1 P a k 2 ; 0 < k 6 1; (3) If l a 1 P l a 3 ; l a 2 P l a 4 ; v a 1 6 v a 3 ; v a 2 6 v a 4 , then a 1 È a 3 P a 2 È a 4 , a 1 a 3 P a 2 a 4 . In fact, if k 1 > k 2 , then 1 À ð1 À l a Þ k 1 P 1 À ð1 À l a Þ k 2 and v k 1 a 6 v k 2 a , therefore, 1 À ð1 À l a Þ k 1 À v k 1 a P 1 À ð1 À l a Þ k 2 À v k 2 a which implies k 1 a P k 2 a; If l a 1 P l a 2 , m a 1 6 m a 2 , then 1 À ð1 À l a 1 Þ k À v k a 1 P 1 À ð1 À l a 2 Þ k À v k a 2 and l k a 1 À ð1 À ð1 À v a 1 Þ k Þ P l k a 2 À ð1 À ð1 À v a 2 Þ k Þ, thus ka 1 P ka 2 and a k 1 P a k 2 ; If l a 1 P l a 3 , l a 2 P l a 4 , v a 1 6 v a 3 and v a 2 6 v a 4 , then l a 1 þ l a 2 À l a 1 l a 2 À v a 1 v a 2 ¼ 1 À ð1 À l a 1 Þð1 À l a 2 Þ À v a 1 v a 2 P 1 À ð1 À l a 3 Þð1 À l a 4 Þ À v a 3 v a 4 ¼ l a 3 þ l a 4 À l a 3 l a 4 À v a 3 v a 4 and l a 1 l a 2 À ðv a 1 þ v a 2 À v a 1 v a 2 Þ ¼ l a 1 l a 2 À 1 þ ð1 À v a 1 Þð1 À v a 2 Þ P l a 3 l a 4 À 1 þ ð1 À v a 3 Þð1 À v a 4 Þ ¼ l a 1 l a 2 À ðv a 3 þ v a 4 À v a 3 v a 4 Þ
div.p: thus, a 1 È a 3 P a 2 È a 4 and a 1 a 3 P a 2 a 4 .

Based on Definitions 2, 3, in the following section, we develop a series of intuitionistic fuzzy power aggregation operators, which allow the input data values to support each other in the aggregation process.

div.head: Intuitionistic fuzzy power aggregation operators
div.p: Let a i ¼ ðl a i ; v a i ; p a i Þ ði ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; nÞ be a collection of IFNs, and w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . ., w n ) T be the weight vector of a i (i = 1,2,. . . , n), where w i P 0, i = 1,2,. . . , n and P n i¼1 w i ¼ 1, then we define an intuitionistic fuzzy power weighted average (IFPWA) operator as follows:
div.formula: IFPWAða 1 ;a 2 ;...;a n Þ ¼ ðw 1 ð1 þ Tða 1 ÞÞa 1 Þ È ðw 2 ð1 þ Tða 2 ÞÞa 2 Þ È ÁÁÁ È ðw n ð1 þ Tða n ÞÞa n Þ P n i¼1 w i ð1 þ Tða i ÞÞð7Þ
div.p: By Definition 3, (7) can be transformed into the following form by using mathematical induction on n:
div.formula: IFPWAða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ 1 À Y n j¼1 ð1 À l a j Þ w j ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞ ; Y n j¼1 ðv a j Þ w j ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞ ; 0 @ Y n j¼1 ð1 À l a j Þ w j ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞ À Y n j¼1 ðv a j Þ w j ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞ 1 Að8Þ
div.p: where
div.formula: Tða i Þ ¼ X n j¼1 j-i w j Supða i ; a j Þ ð 9Þ
div.p: and Sup(a i , a j ) is the support for a i from a j , with the conditions:
(2) Sup(a i ,a j ) = Sup(a j ,a i );
(3) Sup(a i ,a j ) P Sup(a s , a t ), if d(a i , a j ) < d(a s , a t ), where d is a distance measure (such as the normalized Hamming distance or the normalized Euclidean distance [9,8].
Especially, if w = (1/n, 1/n, . . . , 1/n) T , then the IFPWA operator (7) reduces to an intuitionistic fuzzy power average (IFPA) operator:
div.formula: IFPAða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ ð1 þ Tða 1 ÞÞa 1 ð Þ È ð ð 1 þ Tða 2 ÞÞa 2 Þ È Á Á Á È ðð1 þ Tða n ÞÞa n Þ P n i¼1 ð1 þ Tða i ÞÞ ¼ 1 À Y n j¼1 ð1 À l a j Þ ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ ; Y n j¼1 ðv a j Þ ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ ; 0 @ Y n j¼1 ð1 À l a j Þ ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ À Y n j¼1 ðv a j Þ ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ 1 Að10Þ
div.p: where
div.formula: Tða i Þ ¼ 1 n X n j¼1 j-i Supða i ; a j Þ ð11Þ
div.p: It can be easily proved that the IFPWA operator has the following desirable properties: Theorem 1 (Commutativity). Let (a 1 , a 2 , . . ., a n ) be a vector of n IFNs, and a 0 1 ; a 0 2 ; . . . ; a 0 n À Á be any permutation of (a 1 , a 2 , . . ., a n ), then IFPWAða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ IFPWA a 0 1 ; a 0 2 ; . . . ; a
div.formula: 0 n À Áð12Þ
div.p: Theorem 2 (Idempotency). Let a j (j = 1, 2, . . ., n) be a collection of IFNs, if a j = a, for all j, then IFPWAða 1 ; a 2 ; . . .
div.formula: ; a n Þ ¼ að13Þ
div.p: Theorem 3 (Boundedness). Let a j (j = 1, 2, . . . , n) be a collection of IFNs, then a min 6 IFPWAða 1 ; a 2 ; . . .
div.formula: ; a n Þ 6 a maxð14Þ
div.p: where a min ¼ ðmin j fl a j g; max j fv a j gÞ and a max ¼ ðmax j fl a j g; min j fv a j gÞ.
Based on the IFPWA operator (7) and the geometric mean, here we define an intuitionistic fuzzy power weighted geometric (IFPWG) operator:
div.formula: IFPWGða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ ða 1 Þ 1 nÀ1 1À w 1 ð1þTða 1 ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞ ða 2 Þ 1 nÀ1 1À w 2 ð1þTða 2 ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞ Á Á Á ða n Þ 1 nÀ1 1À wn ð1þTðan ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞð15Þ
div.p: which can be transformed into the following form by using mathematical induction on n:
div.formula: IFPWGða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ Y n j¼1 ðl a j Þ 1 nÀ1 1À w j ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞ ; 0 B @ 1 À Y n j¼1 ð1 À v a j Þ 1 nÀ1 1À w j ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞ ; Y n j¼1 ð1 À v a j Þ 1 nÀ1 1À w j ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞ À Y n j¼1 ðl a j Þ 1 nÀ1 1À w j ð1þTða j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTða i ÞÞ 1 C Að16Þ
div.p: with the condition (9). Especially, if w = (1/n, 1/n, . . ., 1/n) T , then the IFPWG operator (16) reduces to an intuitionistic fuzzy power geometric (IFPG) operator:
div.formula: IFPGða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ ða 1 Þ 1 nÀ1 1À 1þTða 1 Þ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ ða 2 Þ 1 nÀ1 1À 1þTða 2 Þ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ Á Á Á ða n Þ 1 nÀ1 1À 1þTðan Þ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ ¼ Y n j¼1 ðl a j Þ 1 nÀ1 1À 1þTða j Þ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ ; 0 B @ 1 À Y n j¼1 ð1 À v a j Þ 1 nÀ1 1À 1þTða j Þ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ ; Y n j¼1 ð1 À v a j Þ 1 nÀ1 1À 1þTða j Þ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ À Y n j¼1 ðl a j Þ 1 nÀ1 1À 1þTða j Þ P n i¼1 ð1þTða i ÞÞ 1 C Að17Þ
div.p: with the condition (11). Similar to the IFPWA operator, the IFPWG operator has the following three properties: Theorem 4 (Commutativity). Let (a 1 , a 2 , . . . , a n ) be a vector of n IFNs, and a 0 1 ; a 0 2 ; . . . ; a 0 n À Á be any permutation of (a 1 ,a 2 ,. . .,a n ), then IFPWGða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ IFPWG a 0 1 ; a 0 2 ; . . . ; a 0 n À Á .
Theorem 5 (Idempotency). Let a j (j = 1, 2, . . . , n) be a collection of IFNs, if a j = a, for all j, then IFPWG(a 1 , a 2 , . . . , a n ) = a.

Theorem 6 (Boundedness). Let a j (j = 1, 2, . . ., n) be a collection of IFNs, then a min 6 IFPWG(a 1 , a 2 , . . . , a n ) 6 a max , where a min ¼ ðmin j fl a j g; max j fv a j gÞ and a max ¼ ðmax j fl a j g; min j fv a j gÞ.

The fundamental characteristic of both the IFPWA and IFPWG operators is that they weight all the given IFNs themselves, and the weighting vectors depend upon the input arguments and allow values being aggregated to support and reinforce each other. However, in many group decision making problems, such as personnel evaluation, diving games, etc., we need to rearrange all the given arguments in descending (or ascending) order, and then weight the ordered positions of the input arguments so as to relieve the influence of unfair arguments on the decision result by assigning low weights to those ''false'' or ''biased'' ones. As a result, motivated by the idea of Yager [25]'s ordered weighted average, in the following, we define an intuitionistic fuzzy power ordered weighted average (IFPOWA) operator:
div.formula: IFPOWAða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ x 1 a indexð1Þ È x 2 a indexð2Þ È Á Á Á È x n a indexðnÞð18Þ
div.p: which can be further expressed as:
div.formula: IFPOWAða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ 1 À Y n j¼1 ð1 À l a indexðjÞ Þ x j ; Y n j¼1 ðv a indexðjÞ Þ x j ; Y n j¼1 ð1 À l a indexðjÞ Þ x j À Y n j¼1 ðv a indexðjÞ Þ x j !ð19Þ
div.p: where a j ¼ ðl a j ; v a j ; p a j Þ ðj ¼ 1; 2 . . . ; nÞ is a collection of IFNs, and index is an indexing function such that index(i) is the index of the ith largest of the IFNs a j (j = 1,2,. . ., n), and thus, a index(i) is the ith largest of the IFNs a j (j = 1,2,. . . , n). x i (i = 1,2,. . . , n) is a collection of weights such that
div.formula: x i ¼ g D i TV À g D iÀ1 TV ; D i ¼ X i j¼1 V indexðjÞ ; TV ¼ X n i¼1 V indexðiÞ ; V indexðjÞ ¼ 1 þ Tða indexðiÞ Þ ð20Þ
div.p: and T(a index(i) ) denotes the support of the ith largest IFN a index(i) by all the other IFNs, i.e.,
div.formula: Tða indexðiÞ Þ ¼ X n j¼1 j-i Supða indexðiÞ ; a indexðjÞ Þ ð21Þ
div.p: where Sup(a index(i) ,a index(j) ) indicates the support of jth largest IFN a index(i) for the ith largest IFN a index(j) , and g: [0, 1] ? [0, 1] is a basic unit-interval monotonic (BUM) function, having the properties: 1) g(0) = 0, 2) g(1) = 1, and 3) g(x) P g(y), if x > y.
Especially, if g(x) = x, then the IFPOWA operator (18) reduces to the IFPA operator (10).
Furthermore, based on the IFPOWA operator ( 18) and the geometric mean, now we define an intuitionistic fuzzy power ordered weighted geometric (IFPOWG) operator:
div.formula: IFPOWGða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ ða indexð1Þ Þ 1Àx 1 nÀ1 ða indexð2Þ Þ 1Àx 2 nÀ1 Á Á Á ða indexðnÞ Þ 1Àxn nÀ1ð22Þ
div.p: which can be further expressed as:
div.formula: IFPOWGða 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n Þ ¼ Y n j¼1 ðl a indexðjÞ Þ 1Àx j nÀ1 ; 1 À Y n j¼1 ð1 À v a indexðjÞ Þ 1Àx j nÀ1 ; Y n j¼1 ð1 À v a indexðjÞ Þ 1Àx j nÀ1 À Y n j¼1 ðl a indexðjÞ Þ 1Àx j nÀ1 !ð23Þ
div.p: where x i (i = 1,2,. . ., n) is a collection of weights satisfying the conditions ( 20) and (21). Especially, if g(x) = x, then the IFPOWG operator (22) reduces to the IFPG operator (17).

Clearly, the weighting vectors of both the IFPWA and IFPWG operators not only depend upon the input arguments and allow values being aggregated to support and reinforce each other, but also emphasize the ordered positions of all the given arguments. Furthermore, the IFPWA and IFPWG operators have also the properties: commutativity, idempotency and boundedness.

div.head: Approaches to multiple attribute group decision making with Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy information
div.p: In this section, we utilize the aggregation operators developed above to multiple attribute group decision making with Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy information:

For a multiple attribute group decision making problem with Atanassov' intuitionistic fuzzy information, let X = {x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n } be a set of n alternatives, G = {G 1 , G 2 , . . . , G m } be a set of m attributes, whose weight vector is w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . ., w m ) T , with w i P 0, i = 1,2,. . . , m, and P m i¼1 w i ¼ 1, and let E = {e 1 , e 2 , . . ., e s } be a set of s decision makers, whose weight vector is k = (k 1 , k 2 , . . . , k s ) T , with k k P 0, k = 1,2,. . . , s, and indicates the degree that the alternative x j does not satisfy the attribute G i , and p ðkÞ ij indicates the uncertainty degree of the alternative x j to the attribute G i , such that
div.formula: P s k¼1 k k ¼ 1. Let A k ¼ ða ðkÞ ij Þ
t ðkÞ ij 2 ½0; 1; f ðkÞ ij 2 ½0; 1; t ðkÞ ij þ f ðkÞ ij 6 1; p ðkÞ ij ¼ 1 À t ðkÞ ij À f ðkÞ ij ; i ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; m; j ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; nð24Þ
div.p: If all the attributes G i (i = 1,2,. . ., m) are of the same type, then the attribute values do not need normalization. Whereas, there are generally benefit attributes (i.e., the bigger the attribute values the better) and cost attributes (i.e., the smaller the attribute values the better) in multiple attribute decision making. In such cases, we may transform the attribute values of cost type into the attribute values of benefit type, then
div.formula: A k ¼ ða ðkÞ ij Þ mÂn can be transformed into intuitionistic fuzzy decision matrix R k ¼ ðr ðkÞ ij Þ mÂn , where r ðkÞ ij ¼ ðl ðkÞ ij ;v ðkÞ ij ; p ðkÞ ij Þ ¼ a ðkÞ ij ; for benefit attribute G i a ðkÞ ij ; for cos t attribute G i 8 < : ; j ¼ 1;2;...;nð25Þ
div.p: where
div.formula: a ðkÞ ij is the complement of a ðkÞ ij , such that a ðkÞ ij ¼ ðf ðkÞ ij ; tðkÞ
ij ; p ðkÞ ij Þ, clearly, p ðkÞ ij ¼ 1 À t ðkÞ ij À f ðkÞ ij ¼ 1 À l ðkÞ ij À v ðkÞ ij .
div.p: Then, we utilize the IFPWA (or IFPWG) operator to develop an approach to multiple attribute group decision making with intuitionistic fuzzy information, which involves the following steps:
div.formula: (Approach I)
div.p: Step 1. Calculate the supports: Sup r
div.formula: ðkÞ ij ; r ðlÞ ij ¼ 1 À dðr ðkÞ ij ; r ðlÞ ij Þ; k; l ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; sð26Þ
div.p: which satisfy the support conditions (1)-( 3) in Section 3. Here, without loss of generality, we calculate dðr
div.formula: ðkÞ ij ; r ðlÞ ij Þ with the normal- ized Hamming distance [9]: d r ðkÞ ij ; r ðlÞ ij ¼ 1 2 l ðkÞ ij À l ðlÞ ij þ v ðkÞ ij À v ðlÞ ij þ p ðkÞ ij À p ðlÞ ij ; k; l ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; sð27Þ
div.p: Step T r
div.formula: ðkÞ ij ¼ X s l¼1 l-k k l Sup rðkÞ
ij ; r ðlÞ ijð28Þ
div.p: and calculate the weights n ðkÞ ij ðk ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; mÞ associated with the IFNs r ðkÞ ij ðk ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; sÞ:

Step 4. To get the overall preference value r j corresponding to the alternative x j , we aggregate all the preference values r ij ði ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; mÞ in the jth column of R by using intuitionistic fuzzy weighted average (IFWA) operator [14]:
div.formula: r j ¼ IFWAðr 1j ; r 2j ; . . . ; r mj Þ ¼ À Y m i¼1 ð1 À l ij Þ w i ; Y m i¼1 ðv ij Þ w i ; Y m i¼1 ð1 À l ij Þ w i À Y m i¼1 ðv ij Þ w i ! ; j ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; nð32Þ
div.p: or the following aggregation operator:
div.formula: r j ¼ IFWGðr 1j ;r 2j ;...;r mj Þ ¼ Y m i¼1 ðl ij Þ 1Àw i mÀ1 ;1À Y m i¼1 ð1Àv ij Þ 1Àw i mÀ1 ; Y m i¼1 ð1Àv ij Þ 1Àw i mÀ1 À Y m i¼1 ðl ij Þ 1Àw i mÀ1 ! ; j ¼ 1;2;...;nð33Þ
div.p: which is defined based on the intuitionistic fuzzy weighted geometric (IFWG) operator [21].
Step 5. Rank r j (j = 1,2,. . . , n) in descending order by using the ranking method described in Definition 2.
Step 6. Rank all the alternatives x j (j = 1,2,. . ., n) and select the best one in accordance with the ranking of r j (j = 1,2,. . . , n).

We have developed two approaches to deal with multiple attribute group decision making problems under two different Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy situations (i.e., 1) the weights of decision makers are known; and (2) the information about the weights of decision makers are completely unknown). Both the approaches can take into account sufficiently the information about the relationships among the arguments being aggregated, and can reduce the influence of outlier arguments on the decision result by assigning lower weights to those outliers and thus can make the decision result more reflective of the total collection of arguments.
In the next two sections, we extend the above aggregation operators and decision making approaches to interval-valued Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy environments.

On the basis of Definitions 4 and 5, in the following, we extend all the operators developed in Section 3 to aggregate interval-valued Atanassov's intuitionistic fuzzy information.

Let ãi ¼ ðlã i ; ṽ ãi ; pã i Þ ði ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; nÞ be a collection of IVIFNs, and w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n ) T be the weight vector of ãi ði ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; nÞ, where w i P 0, i = 1,2,. . .,n and P n i¼1 w i ¼ 1, then we define an interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy power weighted average (IVIFPWA) operator as follows:
div.formula: IVIFPWAð ã1 ; ã2 ; ...; ãn Þ ¼ ðw 1 ð1 þ Tð ã1 ÞÞ ã1 Þ È ðw 2 ð1 þ Tð ã2 ÞÞ ã2 Þ È ÁÁÁ È ðw n ð1 þ Tð ãn ÞÞ ãn Þ P n i¼1 w i ð1 þ Tð ãi ÞÞð43Þ
div.p: which can be transformed into the following form by using mathematical induction on n:
div.formula: IVIFPWAðã 1 ; ã2 ; ...; ãn Þ ¼ 1 À Y n j¼1 1 À l À ãj w j ð1þTðã j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTðã i ÞÞ ; 2 4 0 @ 1 À Y n j¼1 ð1 À l þ ãj Þ w j ð1þTðã j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTðã i ÞÞ 3 5 ; Y n j¼1 ðv À ãj Þ w j ð1þTðã j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTðã i ÞÞ ; Y n j¼1 ðv þ ãj Þ w j ð1þTðã j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTðã i ÞÞ 2 4 3 5 ; Y n j¼1 ð1 À l þ ãj Þ w j ð1þTðã j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTðã i ÞÞ À Y n j¼1 ðv þ ãj Þ w j ð1þTðã j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTðã i ÞÞ ; 2 4 Y n j¼1 ð1 À l À ãj Þ w j ð1þTðã j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTðã i ÞÞ À Y n j¼1 ðv À ãj Þ w j ð1þTðã j ÞÞ P n i¼1 w i ð1þTðã i ÞÞ 3 5 1 Að44Þ

div.p: Based on the IVIFPWA operator (43) and the geometric mean, we define an interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy power weighted geometric (IVIFPWG) operator as follows:

div.p: Then, we utilize the IVIFPWA (or IVIFPWG) operator to develop an approach to multiple attribute group decision making with interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy information, which involves the following steps:
div.formula: (Approach III)
div.p: Step 1. Calculate the supports:

div.head: Practical example
div.p: Now we consider a software selection problem in which alternatives are the software packages to be selected and criteria are those attributes under consideration (adapted from Wang and Lee [10]. A computer center in a university desires to select a new information system in order to improve work productivity. After preliminary screening, four alternatives x j (j = 1, 2, 3, 4) have remained in the candidate list. Three experts e k (k = 1, 2, 3), from a committee to act as decision makers, whose weight vector is k = (0.4, 0.3, 0.3) T . There are four attributes need to be considered:

(1) costs of hardware/software investment (G 1 ); (2) contribution to organization performance (G 2 ); (3) Effort to transform from current systems (G 3 ); and (4) outsourcing software developer reliability (G 4 ). The weight vector of the attributes G i (i = 1, 2, 3, 4) is w = (0.30, 0.25, 0.25, 0.2) T . The experts e k (k = 1, 2, 3) evaluate the software packages x j (j = 1, 2, 3, 4) with respect to the attributes G i (i = 1, 2, 3, 4), and construct the following three intuitionistic fuzzy decision matrices A k ¼ a ðkÞ ij 4Â4 (see Tables 123): Among the considered attributes, G 1 is of cost type, and G i (i = 2, 3, 4) are of benefit type, i.e., the attributes have two different types, and thus we need to transform the attribute values of cost type into the attribute values of benefit type by using (25), then

Similarly, we can utilize Approaches II-IV, respectively to solve multiple attribute group decision making problems where the information about the decision makers is unknown or the attribute values are expressed in IVIFNs.
In the illustrated example, if we use fuzzy sets, each of which is characterized only by a membership information, to express the experts' evaluations, then Tables 4-6 can be written as Tables 789.

Utilize ( 26)-( 29) to calculate the weights n ðkÞ ij ði; j ¼ 1; 2; 3; 4; k ¼ 1; 2; 3Þ associated with the attribute values r ðkÞ ij ði; j ¼ 1; 2; 3; 4; k ¼ 1; 2; 3Þ, which are contained in the matrices D k ¼ ðn ðkÞ ij Þ 4Â4 ðk ¼ 1; 2; 3Þ, respectively (here we assume all the nonmembership degrees and hesitancy degrees are zero): It is noted that the rankings are very different in such two cases, this is because all the nonmembership information and the hesitancy information are lost in the second case, and thus, the final results obtained in the second case are obviously less reasonable than those when the experts' evaluations are expressed in IFNs comprehensively.

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p: We have developed a series of intuitionistic fuzzy aggregation operators the basis of the idea of power aggregation. The prominent characteristic of these operators is that they take into account information about the relationship between the IFNs being aggregated. Then, we have applied our operators to develop some approaches to multiple attribute group decision making with intuitionistic fuzzy information. After that, the extension of the developed operators and decision making approaches to accommodate interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy environments have also been investigated, and a software packages selection problem has been used to illustrate the application and verify the validity of our results.
